bookHvc.on:
• Imaging studies such as PET, CT, or bone scan for staging are not recommended in asymptomatic patients with newly diagnosed stage 0 to II breast cancer.
  • Surveillance blood tests and other imaging tests for breast cancer should not be routinely performed and should be guided by a patient’s symptoms or findings on examination that raise concern for recurrence.
  • Neither radiation therapy nor hormonal therapy provides benefit after bilateral mastectomy for patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (see Question 70).
  • Multigene recurrence assays or gene expression profiles have dramatically improved the ability to avoid chemotherapy for patients at low risk of recurrence who will not benefit from chemotherapy and to identify patients at greater risk who do benefit from chemotherapy (see Question 45).
  • Consensus guidelines indicate that pregnancy after breast cancer should not be discouraged (see Question 16).
  • Second-look laparotomy to assess pathologic response following chemotherapy of ovarian cancer should not be performed.
  • Annual cervical or vaginal cytology should be done on all cervical cancer survivors; additional surveillance imaging and laboratory studies for cervical cancer survivors are recommended only if there are signs or symptoms suggestive of recurrence.
  • PET scans should not be used for preoperative staging or postoperative surveillance in colorectal cancer.
  • PET scans do not add value in the staging of pancreatic cancer and are not part of standard management.
  • Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors are indolent and often initially only require observation and serial imaging.
  • Anal cancer is often curable with combined irradiation and chemotherapy; surgery is typically not indicated (see Question 22).
  • Patients with poor performance status and advanced non–small cell lung cancer without a driver mutation do not benefit from chemotherapy nor immunotherapy and are best served with supportive care (see Question 25).
  • Routine imaging for head and neck cancer after a negative posttreatment scan is not indicated unless signs and symptoms suggest recurrent disease.
  • Although patients who receive radiation therapy that includes the thyroid bed are at increased risk of thyroid cancer, screening thyroid ultrasonography is not indicated.
  • In men with low-risk prostate cancer, active surveillance is a reasonable strategy because some men will never require treatment, and outcomes are no worse if men with low-grade cancer are treated at the time of progression rather than when first diagnosed (see Question 38).
  • Patients with prostate-specific antigen–only recurrence of prostate cancer may be treated with androgen deprivation therapy, although observation is also a reasonable choice.
  • Patients with CT findings pathognomonic for renal cell carcinoma do not need a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is typically an indolent disease, and many patients require no therapy for many years (see Question 49).
  • Physical examination and PET/CT are used to stage patients with Hodgkin lymphoma; laparotomy and splenectomy are no longer performed.
  • Chemotherapy without irradiation is a treatment option for early-stage Hodgkin lymphoma after a complete metabolic response assessed by interim PET/CT after two to three cycles of treatment (risk-adapted therapy) (see Question 36).
  • In patients with a metastatic cancer of unknown primary site, CT and histologic, endoscopic, and gender-specific cancer evaluations are reasonable; however, nonspecific tumor markers, PET, and gene expression arrays should not be done.
  • Palliative or hospice care is appropriate for patients with an unfavorable subtype of cancer of unknown primary site who have comorbidities and poor performance status.
  • Nodal metastases are uncommon in thin melanomas (Breslow depth less than 0.8 mm) and need not be assessed.
  • Most patients with neutropenic fever should be managed with monotherapy with an antipseudomonal β-lactam agent.
  • There is no better therapeutic success but rather an increased risk of toxicity from adding an aminoglycoside to a broad-spectrum β-lactam in the treatment of febrile neutropenia (see Question 33).
  • Growth factors are not routinely used in the treatment of patients with neutropenic fever unless the patient has severe neutropenia (<100/μL [0.1 × 109/L]) expected to last more than 10 days or has other high-risk features.
  • Loop diuretics are not indicated in the treatment of hypercalcemia of malignancy unless kidney failure or heart failure is present; in these circumstances, intravenous expansion of vascular volume should precede the administration of loop diuretics (see Question 43).
  • Spinal cord compression from radiosensitive tumor types, such as leukemia, lymphoma, myeloma, and germ cell tumors, may not require initial surgical decompression; instead, patients may be treated urgently with radiation therapy alone (see Question 63).
bookHvc.hm:
• Lymphopenia without clinical consequences or an associated illness does not require treatment.
  • Bone marrow evaluation need not be undertaken in patients with a monoclonal gammopathy and low-risk features.
  • Patients with low-risk monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance can be clinically observed and do not require follow-up testing (see Question 51).
  • A low mean corpuscular volume, elevated red cell distribution width, and peripheral blood smear showing microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis are virtually diagnostic of iron deficiency, especially in premenopausal women; these findings may render additional testing unnecessary.
  • Iron deficiency is typically treated with oral iron salts, optimally dosed once daily or every other day; oral ferrous sulfate is the preferred preparation because of its tolerability, efficacy, and cost (see Question 59).
  • Supplemental erythropoietin improves anemia of inflammation, but it is associated with worsening hypertension, thrombotic complications, and, in patients with cancer, increased mortality and is not recommended.
  • Patients with anemia of kidney disease who have a hemoglobin level greater than 10 g/dL (100 g/L) should not receive erythropoiesis-stimulating agents.
  • Treatment for cobalamin deficiency should be instituted with oral cobalamin rather than parenteral therapy.
  • Persons with hereditary hemochromatosis and a heterozygous HFE mutation, without symptoms or elevated iron indices, do not require treatment or monitoring (see Question 63).
  • Antiplatelet antibody testing in the diagnosis of immune thrombocytopenic purpura should not be performed.
  • Most patients taking heparin who develop thrombocytopenia but have a low 4T score need no further evaluation.
  • Platelet transfusion is not generally indicated in patients with thrombocytopenia in the absence of trauma, surgery, or bleeding unless the platelet count decreases to less than 10,000 to 20,000/µL (10-20 × 109/L) (see Question 25).
  • Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor is not indicated for most patients with neutropenia who are afebrile, as a routine adjunct to empiric antibiotics for patients presenting with febrile neutropenia, or for patients undergoing induction chemotherapy for acute leukemia (see Question 13).
  • Patients with factor XI deficiency who are asymptomatic do not require prophylactic intervention for most surgeries.
  • Prothrombin complex concentrates should not be used to manage the coagulopathy of liver disease.
  • Thrombophilia testing results generally do not change immediate management, except in high-risk antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (see Question 45).
  • Testing for methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase, as well as measuring homocysteine levels, factor VIII levels, and plasminogen activator inhibitor activity should not be part of the standard thrombophilia evaluation because results do not influence management.
  • Patients with a Pulmonary Embolism Rule-Out Criteria score of zero do not require further testing with D-dimer or imaging (see Question 56).
  • Patients with low probability for deep venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism should undergo D-dimer testing; if the results are normal, no further imaging is necessary.
  • Most patients with deep venous thrombosis and those with pulmonary embolism who have a good prognosis can be safely managed without hospitalization.
  • Bridging anticoagulation therapy is not indicated for most patients because it is associated with more bleeding complications without any reduction in thrombotic events.
  • Patients with gestational thrombocytopenia do not require treatment.
bookHvc.en:
• Tight inpatient glycemic control (80-110 mg/dL [4.4-6.1 mmol/L]) is not consistently associated with improved outcomes and may increase mortality.
  • The sole use of correction insulin (“sliding-scale insulin”) in hospitalized patients is not recommended because it is a reactive, nonphysiologic approach that leads to large glucose fluctuations.
  • Sulfonylureas stimulate insulin secretion regardless of glycemic status and commonly cause hypoglycemia and are associated with weight gain (see Question 84).
  • The use of any opioids for management of chronic neuropathic pain carries the risk for addiction and should be avoided (see Question 67).
  • Patients with asymptomatic pituitary microadenomas do not require treatment.
  • Evaluation for Cushing syndrome should be limited to patients with a significant clinical suspicion of disease, including specific signs of Cushing syndrome or an adrenal mass.
  • Imaging for pheochromocytoma should be performed only after documentation of elevated catecholamine levels (see Question 76).
  • Imaging studies for pancreatogenous insulinoma or noninsulinoma tumor localization should only occur after confirmation of endogenous hyperinsulinism.
  • In patients taking an ACE inhibitor or an angiotensin receptor blocker, a simple initial test for primary aldosteronism is a plasma renin activity measurement; a non-suppressed plasma renin level rules out mineralocorticoid excess.
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy is not recommended for subcentimeter thyroid nodules unless associated with symptoms, pathologic lymphadenopathy, extrathyroidal extension, history of childhood radiation exposure, or familial thyroid cancer syndrome.
  • Triiodothyronine measurement in the setting of hypothyroidism is not necessary or recommended; normal levels are maintained unless hypothyroidism is severe.
  • Thyroid peroxidase antibodies are present in most patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis, but measurement is unnecessary unless the diagnosis is unclear.
  • Triiodothyronine-containing compounds are not recommended to treat hypothyroidism because of their short half-life, which causes spikes in triiodothyronine levels.
  • No evidence supports that treatment of subclinical hypothyroidism improves quality of life, cognitive function, blood pressure, or weight (see Question 54).
  • Treatment of nonthyroidal illness syndrome is not recommended because of a lack of significant clinical benefit.
  • Thyroid function should not be assessed in hospitalized patients unless there is a strong clinical suspicion of thyroid dysfunction.
  • In secondary hypothyroidism, measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone should not be performed because it cannot be used to monitor therapy (see Question 30).
  • Screening for hypogonadism in men with nonspecific symptoms is not recommended.
  • Testosterone therapy in men without biochemical evidence of deficiency has not been shown to be beneficial and is associated with many harms.
  • Loop diuretics in the treatment of moderate to severe hypercalcemia are not recommended in the absence of kidney failure or volume overload.
  • Routine screening for vitamin D deficiency is not recommended in healthy populations.
  • Bone mineral density measurements on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry before and during teriparatide therapy are not used to assess adequacy of response or to revise estimates of fracture risk (see Question 18).
  • In otherwise healthy young adults, a low-energy fracture is not an indication for bone mineral density measurement (see Question 23).
bookHvc.pm:
• A key clinical indicator of occupational asthma is symptom improvement during weekends and time away from work; spirometry before and after workplace exposures is a cost-effective way to confirm a suspected diagnosis of occupational asthma.
  • Fractional exhaled nitric oxide measurement (FeNO) is not recommended to guide asthma treatment in the general population (see Question 85).
  • Administration of a glucocorticoid and a long-acting β2-agonist in a single inhaler is preferred because it improves adherence and may reduce cost compared with administration of each drug in a separate inhaler (see Question 13).
  • In patients with COPD exacerbation, short courses of lower-dose oral glucocorticoids (prednisone 40 mg/d for 5 days) have been found to be equivalent to higher doses, longer courses, and intravenous administration (see Question 64).
  • A sputum culture is not routinely used to assess COPD exacerbations, as it rarely affects management.
  • Patients not using baseline oxygen and with a resting SpO2 of less than 92% should be prescribed supplemental oxygen during air travel without additional testing (see Question 82).
  • When high-resolution CT findings are classic for usual interstitial pneumonia, lung biopsy is not necessary for diagnosis.
  • The diagnosis of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) may not require lung biopsy if the clinical presentation and high-resolution CT findings are consistent with COP.
  • In patients with radiographic evidence of advanced-stage lung cancer, diagnosis and staging are best accomplished with a single invasive test at a location that will establish both the diagnosis and the stage of disease.
  • Benzodiazepines should not be used for treating delirium unless they are needed to treat alcohol withdrawal or seizures.
  • In patients receiving enteral feedings, routine measurement of gastric residuals is not recommended because it delays achievement of feeding goals, increases the risk of clogging the enteral access, and may increase the risk for aspiration.
  • Administration of parenteral nutrition to supplement enteral nutrition may lead to harm and should be avoided.
  • Bronchoscopy for airway mucous clearance to prevent postoperative atelectasis offers no clear benefit compared with other methods of chest physiotherapy.
  • Evidence for pulmonary artery catheters demonstrates a lack of benefit and, in some cases, increased risk to patients.
  • Given the relative expense of colloids, crystalloid administration is generally preferred and recommended by guidelines in the treatment of septic shock.
  • There is no role for glucocorticoids in sepsis without shock.
  • Clinical presentations of sarcoidosis that do not require a biopsy include asymptomatic stage I pulmonary sarcoidosis, Löfgren syndrome, and Heerfordt syndrome (see Question 16).
  • Providing supplemental oxygen in acutely ill medical patients with normal oxygen saturation increases mortality in a dose-dependent manner and is not recommended (see Question 45).
  • Approximately 20% of laboratory tests obtained in hospitalized patients are not needed (see Question 76).
  • Excessive laboratory testing in hospitalized patients can result in iatrogenic anemia (see Question 76).
  • Discontinuing antibiotic therapy is appropriate in patients who initially were thought to have sepsis but do not (see Question 96).
  • In older persons with nonexertional hyperthermia, ice water immersion is associated with increased mortality and should not be used (see Question 4).
  • In patients with portal hypertension and acute gastrointestinal bleeding, transfusion to 10 g/dL (100 g/L) or higher can rapidly increase portal pressure, putting the patient at significant risk for rebleeding, and is not recommended (see Question 53).
bookHvc.nr:
• Stable headaches meeting criteria for most primary headaches usually do not require imaging.
  • Nonpharmacologic treatment strategies, such as relaxation training and cognitive behavioral therapy, should be considered for all patients with tension-type headache (see Question 6).
  • The monoclonal antibodies erenumab, fremanezumab, eptinezumab, and galcanezumab should be considered for migraine prophylaxis only after two or three adequate but unsuccessful trials of first-line preventive medications (see Question 70).
  • After a single unprovoked seizure with no abnormalities on MRI or electroencephalography and with no risk factors for epilepsy, antiepileptic drug therapy is typically withheld.
  • The dosing strategy for antiepileptic drug therapy in older adults can be summarized as “start low and go slow” because older adults usually require lower antiepileptic drug doses and are at increased risk of interactions and decreased drug clearance (see Question 74).
  • The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force does not recommend screening for carotid artery stenosis in the general adult population (see Question 78).
  • In the evaluation of transient ischemic attack, carotid ultrasonography is a low-cost, readily available test not associated with radiation and should be performed emergently in order to identify patients who may require surgery (see Question 95).
  • Supplemental oxygen in patients with normal oxygen saturation as measured by pulse oximetry increases mortality in patients with acute stroke (see Question 27).
  • The use of transesophageal echocardiography to evaluate for an intracardiac source of stroke is not routinely indicated.
  • Transthoracic echocardiography with agitated saline injection is indicated in younger patients with stroke without other risk factors and is less invasive than other imaging procedures (see Question 66).
  • Routine internal carotid artery revascularization for primary prevention of stroke is not warranted unless high-risk stroke features are present, such as stenosis greater than 80% or rapid progression of stenosis.
  • Symptomatic high-grade intracranial arterial stenosis is associated with a high risk of recurrent stroke, but stenting of the affected artery is associated with a high risk of procedural stroke and should be avoided.
  • Acute administration of anticoagulation in ischemic strokes does not reduce the short-term risk of recurrent stroke and increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage (see Question 77).
  • Long-term use of combination aspirin-clopidogrel is associated with no reduction in risk of stroke but an increased risk of hemorrhage and death when compared with single-agent antiplatelet use.
  • Aspirin is preferred to rivaroxaban or dabigatran in the secondary prevention of stroke in patients with embolic stroke of undetermined origin (see Question 85).
  • Routine use of platelet transfusion in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage who are being treated with anti-platelet agents is not indicated.
  • Aneurysms less than 7 millimeters in diameter in the posterior circulation and less than 12 millimeters in the anterior circulation can be managed conservatively with annual noninvasive neuroimaging.
  • Medications, vitamin, and herbal supplements do not prevent cognitive decline in healthy people or in patients with mild cognitive impairment (see Question 25).
  • Specialized tests for dementia—including cerebrospinal fluid tests, dopamine transporter single-photon emission CT and PET scans—should be reserved for uncertain diagnoses or atypical presentations.
  • No medications are currently approved for the treatment of mild cognitive impairment, and no medications or dietary agents have been shown to prevent progression to dementia once reversible causes have been excluded.
  • There is no evidence of benefit of memantine in the treatment of mild stage of Alzheimer dementia (see Question 43).
  • In the absence of a clear response to either high-volume cerebrospinal fluid removal or lumbar drainage, a permanent ventricular shunt to treat normal pressure hydrocephalus should not be pursued (see Question 22).
  • In the evaluation of delirium, a head CT scan or MRI of the brain should be reserved for patients with focal findings on the neurologic examination that suggest an intracerebral process, such as ischemic stroke or hemorrhage (see Question 56).
  • In Parkinson disease, a dopamine transporter single-photon emission CT scan of the brain is unnecessary except to differentiate between Parkinson disease and essential tremor or drug-induced parkinsonism if the distinction cannot be made on clinical grounds.
  • A positive pull test is the most reliable predictor of a risk of backward falls in Parkinson disease.
  • Treatment of periodic leg movement of sleep is required only if it causes marked sleep fragmentation (see Question 68).
  • In the treatment of refractory essential tremor, deep-brain stimulation results in greater functional improvements than thalamotomy and fewer adverse events, such as dysarthria, sensory disturbances, and gait disturbances (see Question 76).
  • Any patient with a suspected relapse of multiple sclerosis should be screened for causes of Uhthoff phenomenon (transient worsening of neurologic symptoms associated with increased body temperature) masquerading as a relapse (or “pseudorelapse”) to avoid unnecessary treatment.
  • Disease-modifying therapy should be discontinued in patients with secondary progressive multiple sclerosis who have been nonambulatory for more than 2 years and who have had no relapsing activity during that same period (see Question 50).
  • MRI is the preferred initial imaging test for most patients with findings of myelopathy (see Question 3).
  • In classic Bell palsy, brain imaging and laboratory testing is not required.
  • Plasma exchange and intravenous immunoglobulin are equally effective treatment options for Guillain-Barré syndrome, but combination therapy is no more effective than either modality alone (see Question 73).
  • In patients with central nervous system tumors not associated with seizures, prophylactic antiepileptic drugs are not recommended.
  • Meningiomas are benign dural-based tumors that require no management in asymptomatic patients and are usually followed clinically (see Question 10).
  • In patients with metastatic spinal compression, surgical decompression should be reserved for patients younger than 65 years with a single area of compression, para- plegia for less than 48 hours, and a predicted survival of longer than 6 months (see Question 49).
  • In patients with suspected central nervous system lymphoma, the finding of lymphomatous cells in vitreous or cerebrospinal fluid samples (identified by cytology and flow cytometry) may obviate the need for biopsy (see Question 67).
bookHvc.id:
• Uninfected diabetic foot wounds should not be cultured or treated with antibiotics.
  • Diagnostic studies to identify a causative organism are not routinely indicated in outpatients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) but should be considered in non-ICU hospitalized patients when this information would change management; diagnostic studies should be performed in all patients admitted to the ICU with CAP.
  • Patients with community-acquired pneumonia requiring hospitalization can be treated with the standard inpatient regimens regardless of a documented aspiration event (see Question 7).
  • Most patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia only require treatment for 7 days; exceptions include patients who have bacteremia, have a metastatic infection, show slow response to therapy, are immunocompromised, or have pyogenic complications (see Question 107).
  • In adults with community-acquired pneumonia whose symptoms have resolved within 5 to 7 days, routine follow-up chest imaging is usually not necessary.
  • Early localized Lyme disease usually presents within 4 weeks of infection and is characterized by erythema migrans (EM) at the site of tick attachment; patients with EM and a compatible exposure history do not require confirmatory laboratory testing and should receive oral doxycycline.
  • Post–Lyme disease syndrome (fatigue, arthralgia, myalgia, and impairment of memory or cognition) can last for years, even after appropriate treatment; prolonged antibiotics are not effective in treating this condition.
  • Urine culture is not recommended in women with uncomplicated cystitis but is indicated in pyelonephritis, complicated cystitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, patients with multiple antibiotic allergies, and in patients with a suspected resistant organism.
  • Pyuria accompanying asymptomatic bacteriuria is not an indication for urine culture or antimicrobial treatment.
  • Urine culture with susceptibility testing is required in acute pyelonephritis before initiation of empiric therapy; follow-up urine cultures are only indicated in pregnant women.
  • Imaging studies are only necessary in patients with pyelonephritis and fever for more than 72 hours, in persistent bacteremia, or when complications are suspected.
  • Screening for and treating asymptomatic bacteriuria before nonurologic surgical procedures is not recommended (see Question 49).
  • In women with recurrent cystitis, self-treatment with a first-line, short-course regimen (such as nitrofurantoin) is an appropriate initial strategy (see Question 36).
  • Test of cure is not recommended in patients with Chlamydia trachomatis infection except in pregnancy; however, patients should be retested for possible repeat infection after 3 months or at their next medical visit.
  • Because of its low cost and specificity, plain radiography is recommended as an initial imaging test for suspected osteomyelitis; if radiography is negative, MRI, with and without intravenous contrast, should be obtained.
  • In patients with vertebral osteomyelitis and positive blood cultures for a typical pathogen, bone biopsy is generally not indicated (see Question 28).
  • Oral antibiotics (such as doxycycline) with high bioavailability have been shown to be noninferior to intravenous antibiotics for the management of osteomyelitis (see Question 87).
  • In patients with classic fever of unknown origin (fever >38.3 °C [100.9 °F] for >3 weeks that remains undiagnosed after careful extensive evaluation and two visits in the ambulatory setting), no further testing or treatment is indicated (see Question 67).
  • Fluid replacement is the mainstay of treatment for travelers’ diarrhea; azithromycin and fluoroquinolones are recommended only in severe disease.
  • Most uncomplicated Salmonella infections in adults younger than 50 years resolve within 1 week and require only supportive care; when empiric treatment is indicated for those with more severe or invasive disease, fluoroquinolones (such as ciprofloxacin) are most likely to be effective.
  • Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli infection is usually a self-limited illness that resolves without treatment after approximately 4 days; hydration and empiric antibiotic therapy with fluoroquinolones, azithromycin, or rifaximin are recommended in travelers when symptoms restrict activities.
  • Diarrhea caused by Campylobacter usually resolves spontaneously (see Question 57).
  • Prophylaxis and immunization are preferred over treating active infections after transplantation.
  • Hand hygiene is the foundation of infection prevention; the World Health Organization has identified five key hand hygiene moments (before touching a patient, before clean or aseptic procedure, after body fluid exposure risk, after touching a patient, and after touching patient surroundings).
  • Catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria is common and generally does not require treatment.
  • Candiduria in a patient with a catheter frequently represents colonization and rarely requires treatment.
  • Antimicrobial- or antiseptic-coated catheters have not shown benefit for short-term or long-term catheterization, are more expensive, and, in some cases, cause more discomfort for patients.
  • Reconfirmation of the diagnosis of herpes simplex virus infection before treatment is not needed in the setting of a consistent clinical presentation (see Question 44).
  • Avoiding unnecessary antibiotic use, simplifying unnecessary combination therapy, avoiding double anaerobic coverage, converting intravenous to oral agents, streamlining de-escalation, and minimizing therapy duration are important components of antimicrobial stewardship programs.
bookHvc.gi:
• In patients with symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease but without alarm features, an empiric trial of a proton pump inhibitor is the initial management.
  • Candida esophagitis can be diagnosed clinically in patients with dysphagia and odynophagia, immunosuppression, and findings of oral thrush (see Question 89).
  • PPI therapy should be used at the lowest dose needed to control gastroesophageal reflux symptoms and discontinued if there is no appropriate indication (see Question 44).
  • For patients with dyspepsia, routine upper endoscopy to exclude malignancy is reserved for patients age 60 years and older.
  • In countries with a low incidence of gastric cancer, such as the United States, screening for gastric cancer should be reserved for patients with genetic cancer syndromes.
  • For patients with dyspepsia, a “test and treat” strategy for Helicobacter pylori infection is recommended (see Question 70).
  • Routine repeat upper endoscopy for gastric ulcer is not recommended (see Question 73).
  • Patients with acute pancreatitis should undergo transabdominal ultrasonography rather than CT for evaluation of biliary disease.
  • Routine use of antibiotics is not warranted in acute pancreatitis (see Question 12).
  • Patients with acute pancreatitis should resume feeding when pain improves and any nausea or vomiting subsides; oral feeding is preferred (see Question 16).
  • Evaluation for centrally mediated pain syndrome requires a detailed medical and psychosocial history and physical examination, with limited laboratory testing.
  • Acute diverticulitis is often a clinical diagnosis, usually not requiring abdominal imaging unless an alternative diagnosis or complicated disease is suspected.
  • Lactase deficiency can be diagnosed on the basis of improvement after exclusion of dietary lactose or administration of lactase enzymes with meals (see Question 37).
  • The most common cause of recurrent celiac disease symptoms is gluten exposure (see Question 45).
  • Many drugs can cause chronic diarrhea; discontinuing a potential culprit drug may relieve symptoms and obviate the need for further diagnostic testing (see Question 59).
  • Antibiotics are not recommended for mild traveler’s diarrhea (see Question 86).
  • Irritable bowel syndrome is a common cause of diarrhea and can be diagnosed on clinical grounds, including history and physical examination (see Question 22).
  • Empiric antibiotic therapy with monitoring for improvement in symptoms may be reasonable in patients with a high probability of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (see Question 67).
  • Elastography is a noninvasive imaging technique that assesses liver stiffness as a measure of fibrosis and may avoid biopsy.
  • Asymptomatic hepatic cysts are benign and require no follow-up.
  • Focal nodular hyperplasia does not have malignant potential or a risk for bleeding and does not require follow-up.
  • No information indicates that the addition of α-fetoprotein (AFP) to ultrasonography screening for hepatocellular carcinoma leads to improved survival; therefore, surveillance using ultrasonography may be performed with or without AFP measurement every 6 months (see Question 30).
  • The mainstay of management of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is weight loss (see Question 35).
  • Management of chronic pain in patients with chronic liver disease should always include physical therapy because it will not exacerbate the manifestations of chronic liver disease (see Question 82).
  • Patients in the immune control phase of chronic HBV infection, also known as inactive chronic HBV infection, generally do not require treatment (see Question 4).
  • Uncomplicated diverticulitis is treated with oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin or metronidazole) and a liquid diet (see Question 6).
  • Incidental gallstones do not typically cause symptoms, and prophylactic cholecystectomy and other treatments are generally not recommended (see Question 78).
  • In acute cholecystitis, cholecystectomy during the initial hospitalization is associated with improved clinical outcomes and lower costs compared with delayed cholecystectomy (see Question 74).
  • For patients with mild gallstone pancreatitis, same-admission cholecystectomy reduces rates of gallstone-related complications compared with cholecystectomy 25 to 30 days after hospital discharge (see Question 96).
  • Patients with peptic ulcer disease and low-risk stigmata can be fed within 24 hours of endoscopy, receive once-daily oral PPI therapy, and be discharged from the hospital.
  • In uncomplicated asymptomatic patients with iron deficiency anemia and negative bidirectional endoscopy, a trial of initial iron supplementation over the routine use of video capsule endoscopy is conditionally suggested by the American Gastroenterological Association (see Question 60).
  • The risk for rebleeding in patients with high-risk ulcers that are successfully treated endoscopically is similar for patients who receive twice-daily intravenous PPI and those who receive continuous PPI infusion; twice-daily PPI is preferable given the similar clinical efficacy and lower cost (see Question 88).
  • When there is no evidence that a patient’s requested diagnostic or therapeutic intervention will provide clinical benefit, physicians are not obligated to provide the service (see Question 58).
bookHvc.np:
• The random (spot) urine protein-creatinine ratio and albumin-creatinine ratio correlate with 24-hour urine collections and are sufficiently accurate for screening and monitoring proteinuria.
  • There is no need to monitor urine protein excretion in patients who are taking an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker.
  • In the treatment of diabetic kidney disease, combining any two renin-angiotensin system drug classes (ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, or direct renin inhibitors) is not recommended, as side effects are increased and there is no additional clinical benefit.
  • Urinalysis should not be used for urothelial cancer screening in asymptomatic adults.
  • CT urography is preferred to MRI as the diagnostic test of choice for patients with unexplained hematuria (see Question 59).
  • In the treatment of symptomatic hyponatremia, simultaneous administration of desmopressin with 3% saline infusion results in a more predictable and safer increase in serum sodium (see Question 90).
  • The treatment of isovolemic hypernatremia is water, preferably orally or by nasogastric tube if the patient is incapable of drinking, rather than intravenously (see Question 60).
  • Baseline echocardiography is not routinely recommended but should be performed if examination or ECG suggest cardiac hypertrophy or to evaluate the need for therapy in patients with white coat hypertension.
  • Adults with stage 1 hypertension who have an estimated 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease event risk of <10% should be managed initially with nonpharmacologic therapy (see Question 52).
  • Treatment of chronic hypertension (<160/110 mm Hg) during pregnancy is not associated with improved fetal outcomes (see Question 13).
  • In most patients with renal artery stenosis, the primary therapeutic intervention is medical management (see Question 18).
  • For patients with suspected renal artery fibromuscular dysplasia, CT angiography is preferred to MRI as the initial imaging modality of choice (see Question 48).
  • In younger patients with IgA nephropathy, recurrent hematuria in the absence of proteinuria usually portends a benign clinical course and treatment is conservative (see Question 41).
  • Serologic testing for anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies in patients with suspected primary membranous nephropathy can eliminate the need for kidney biopsy in patients with preserved kidney function and no evidence of secondary causes (see Question 75).
  • Primary membranous nephropathy is typically treated with conservative therapy before initiating immunosuppression for patients with persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria to allow for spontaneous remission, which occurs in approximately 30% of patients.
  • Contrast-associated nephropathy prophylaxis is not indicated for patients with a stable estimated glomerular filtration rate ≥45 mL/min/1.73 m2 (see Question 2).
  • There is no proven benefit to early administration of renal replacement therapy versus timing based on usual clinical criteria in critically ill patients or those with sepsis.
  • In the diagnosis of nephrolithiasis, ultrasonography does not expose patients to radiation, has a lower cost compared with CT, and is the preferred modality during pregnancy (see Question 69).
  • The most effective treatment to facilitate the passage of uric acid stones is urinary alkalinization with potassium citrate (see Question 54).
  • Use of potassium binders in patients with chronic kidney disease may allow continuation of essential medications, such as inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system (see Question 106).
  • Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents should not be used for most patients with chronic kidney disease and hemoglobin >11 g/dL (110 g/L) because of an increased risk for serious cardiovascular events and stroke.
  • For older patients with end-stage kidney disease and those who are not transplant candidates, screening for renal cell carcinoma is not recommended, even in the presence of known acquired cystic kidney disease (see Question 5).
  • For eligible patients, kidney transplantation is the preferred treatment for end-stage kidney disease because of improved mortality and quality of life and decreased health care costs.
  • Patients who receive preparatory renal replacement therapy (RRT) education before they are diagnosed with end-stage kidney disease are more likely to select a home modality for RRT, be listed for a kidney transplant, or receive a preemptive kidney transplant and may have a mortality benefit compared with patients who do not receive similar education (see Question 46).
  • Non-dialytic palliative therapy is a reasonable option for older patients with end-stage kidney disease and multiple comorbidities, with treatment focusing on symptom management and quality of life.
bookHvc.gm2:
• The ordering of excessive tests and procedures to avoid malpractice litigation leads to waste and potential harm through unnecessary testing and treatment (see Question 84).
  • Routine testing beyond the history and physical examination is not necessary in the preparticipation physical examination (see Question 87).
  • The use of β-carotene or vitamin E supplements for the prevention of cardiovascular disease or cancer is not recommended.
  • Urinalysis is not indicated before joint arthroplasty in asymptomatic patients (see Question 30).
  • Patients whose laboratory test results in the past 4 months were normal and whose clinical status is stable do not need repeat testing before surgery (see Question 30).
  • Patients with less than 1% risk for perioperative major adverse cardiac event may proceed to surgery without additional testing.
  • Preoperative ECG should not be performed in patients undergoing low-risk procedures.
  • Patients with coronary artery disease should not undergo routine coronary angiography or revascularization before surgery exclusively to reduce perioperative events.
  • Chest radiography, arterial blood gas analysis, or spirometry is not routinely indicated in the preoperative evaluation of patients with chronic lung disease (see Question 23).
  • There is no benefit of incentive spirometry, with or without deep breathing exercises, in preventing postoperative pulmonary complications (see Question 111).
  • Patients with untreated, asymptomatic mild hypothyroidism may proceed to surgery without further testing or treatment.
  • Pregnant patients should undergo the same preoperative medical evaluation as nonpregnant patients; additional diagnostic testing is unnecessary.
  • There is little evidence that over-the-counter weight loss supplements are effective.
  • Aspirin should be used infrequently in primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (see Question 77).
  • Routine screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in women who have never smoked and who have no family history of AAA is not recommended (see Question 97).
  • Do not screen for coronary artery disease with either resting or exercise ECG in asymptomatic patients at low risk (see Question 22).
  • Clinicians should not use clinical breast examination to screen for breast cancer.
  • Ultrasonography is preferred to mammography in the evaluation of a breast mass in women younger than 30 years.
  • Routine laboratory testing for the diagnosis of menopause is not recommended.
  • Nonhormonal therapies are preferred to topical vaginal estrogen as first-line treatments for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (see Question 1).
  • The preferred colorectal screening strategy is the one most likely to be completed by the patient (see Question 67).
  • Clinicians should not screen men for prostate cancer unless they express a preference for screening (see Question 106).
  • Observation is recommended for uncomplicated acute otitis media in adults and children.
  • Antibiotic therapy is ineffective in the treatment for the common cold or acute rhinosinusitis and is not recommended (see Question 42).
  • Patients with acute pharyngitis who present with fewer than three Centor criteria do not need to be tested or treated for bacterial pharyngitis.
  • There is a generic equivalent in each class of topical glucocorticoids, allowing for a cost-effective approach.
  • Combined topical glucocorticoids and antifungal agents should be avoided because they can worsen some tinea infections and may cause striae.
  • Inexpensive treatment of seborrheic dermatitis includes over-the-counter medications, such as selenium sulfide or zinc pyrithione shampoos.
  • Diagnostic evaluation for urticaria is not recommended unless the history suggests a specific cause.
  • Topical antihistamines for urticaria are not recommended because they are ineffective and may lead to allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Pruritus may persist for weeks after eradication of scabies and does not require retreatment.
  • Treatment of onychomycosis is unnecessary in most cases.
  • Warts are usually self-limited and treatment is unnecessary.
  • Perioperative glucocorticoid stress dosing may not be required in many patients receiving low-dose and short-course glucocorticoid therapy (see Question 4).
  • The choice of a topical broad-spectrum antibiotic for bacterial conjunctivitis is usually empiric; the most convenient or least expensive option can be selected (see Question 17).
bookHvc.rm:
• An accurate history and a thorough musculoskeletal physical examination are essential to diagnose and differentiate inflammatory and noninflammatory symptoms and can help to avoid unnecessary testing.
  • Antinuclear antibody testing should not be performed in a patient with nonspecific symptoms and normal findings on clinical examination because it does not establish the diagnosis of a connective tissue disease.
  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) subserology testing should not be performed routinely, even in the setting of a positive ANA result, without strong clinical suspicion of an underlying connective tissue disease.
  • Radiography is usually the first imaging test ordered in the evaluation of rheumatologic diseases because it is readily available, is inexpensive, exposes patients to only a low level of ionizing radiation, and is useful in monitoring arthritis progression.
  • Ultrasonography is an inexpensive means to assess soft-tissue abnormalities, assess disease activity, and assist with tendon or joint injections.
  • All tumor necrosis factor inhibitors provide similar benefit in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (see Question 36).
  • Laboratory testing is usually not necessary to diagnose osteoarthritis but is helpful if other causes of arthritis are being considered or to help define the safety of potential therapies.
  • Topical NSAIDs are safe and effective for treatment of knee and hand osteoarthritis and should be considered before oral NSAIDs (see Question 24).
  • The use of chondroitin sulfate (with or without glucosamine), biologics, intra-articular hyaluronic acid, platelet-rich plasma, stem cells, or botulinum toxin is not recommended in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis (see Question 50).
  • Acetaminophen provides no benefit for hip or knee osteoarthritis; it may be considered as add-on therapy for short-term and episodic use but not as initial therapy (see Question 54).
  • Tai chi is as beneficial as physical therapy for knee and hip osteoarthritis pain (see Question 34).
  • Exercise is beneficial in hip, knee, and hand osteoarthritis; no one exercise program is superior (see Question 82).
  • Arthroscopic surgery is not indicated in patients with osteoarthritis unless there is joint buckling, instability, or locking, or a concomitant and symptomatic mechanical disorder.
  • Patients with fibromyalgia should not be treated with anti-inflammatory drugs, including NSAIDs and glucocorticoids, and do not respond to opioids, with the exception of tramadol (see Question 7).
  • Borrelia burgdorferi DNA can be detected by polymerase chain reaction in synovial fluid, but this test offers no advantage to serologic testing (see Question 12).
  • A muscle biopsy is not necessary to diagnose dermatomyositis in patients with characteristic clinical and laboratory findings (see Question 38).
  • A muscle biopsy can help to confirm the diagnosis of inclusion body myositis but is not needed when clinical features are characteristic (see Question 45).
  • In the absence of additional suggestive symptoms, physical findings, and supporting laboratory data, oral dryness should not be attributed to a rheumatologic condition (see Question 47).
  • If a patient has many features of spondyloarthritis, a positive HLA-B27 result adds little to the posttest probability (see Question 5).
  • Antibiotics generally are not indicated in reactive arthritis because they do not affect illness outcomes (see Question 67).
bookHvc.gm:
• Physicians are not obligated to provide diagnostic or therapeutic interventions for which there is no evidence of clinical benefit.
  • Chest radiography is not indicated in the evaluation of acute cough in the absence of abnormal vital signs or lung examination findings, unless there are other concerning clinical features (e.g., altered mental status).
  • Antibiotics are not recommended in patients with acute bronchitis or upper respiratory tract infection without a clear bacterial cause.
  • The mainstay of treatment of acute cough due to bronchitis is patient education; antitussive agents have limited efficacy (see Question 55).
  • The diagnostic test of choice for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver; routine imaging is not recommended.
  • Point-of-care lung ultrasonography is an accurate means of rapidly detecting pleural effusion, interstitial syndromes, alveolar consolidation, and pneumothorax, and it is safer and less expensive than radiography and CT.
  • The treatment of systemic exertion intolerance disease focuses on nonpharmacologic therapies; pharmacologic therapies have not been shown to be consistently effective (see Question 91).
  • Polysomnography is usually unnecessary in the evaluation of insomnia unless the clinical presentation suggests a sleep disorder.
  • Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia is preferred to pharmacologic therapy as first-line treatment for insomnia.
  • Routine use of systemic antibiotics is not recommended for the treatment of venous stasis ulcers.
  • In patients with medically unexplained symptoms, diagnostic testing should be limited, because unrevealing studies provide negligible reassurance, pose iatrogenic risks, and result in additional patient anxiety.
  • In patients with medically unexplained symptoms, it may be more beneficial and value-driven to assess and treat any potential underlying psychological symptoms and to educate patients on successful coping skills (see Question 10).
  • An ECG should be obtained in all patients with syncope; brain imaging, cardiac enzymes, and metabolic profile have low diagnostic yield and should be performed only when there is a moderate to high pretest probability of a specific underlying condition.
  • Patients with vasovagal syncope may be discharged from the emergency department without costly testing or procedures (see Question 70).
  • Compared with usual care, specialty palliative medicine improves overall quality of life, physical symptom burden, mood, and caregiver satisfaction with patient care in the setting of serious illness.
  • No specific dressing for venous ulcer stands out as superior in direct comparisons; dry gauze should be avoided because it disrupts the formation of granulation tissue when removed (see Question 27).
  • Enteral or parenteral artificial nutritional support at the end of life does not improve survival, is invasive, and may cause side effects.
  • In the setting of serious illness, docusate sodium for constipation is no better than placebo (see Question 112).
  • In patients with persistently debilitating dyspnea despite maximal medical therapy, nonpharmacologic treatment strategies, such as pursed lip breathing, and devices that enhance airflow are the least invasive and easiest to administer to reduce severity of symptoms (see Question 80).
  • Compared with second-generation antidepressants, psychostimulants (dextroamphetamine, methylphenidate, and pemoline) should be considered in the treatment of depression at the end of life because they take effect quickly (see Question 9).
  • Most patients with nonspecific low back pain do not require imaging or other diagnostic testing.
  • Nonpharmacologic therapies are considered a cornerstone of treatment for acute and chronic low back pain; opioid therapy should be avoided.
  • Patient education can provide long-term reassurance for patients with acute or subacute low back pain and reduces low back pain–related primary care visits more than usual care (see Question 99).
  • Most patients with neck pain do not require imaging studies; plain radiography should be performed when evaluation suggests fracture, infection, or cancer and may be considered for cervical sprain that is unresponsive to 6 to 8 weeks of conservative therapy.
  • Most patients with rotator cuff disease do not require imaging studies or surgery; treatment may include education, avoidance or modification of aggravating activities, physical therapy, and acetaminophen or NSAIDs.
  • Nonsurgical management of olecranon bursitis is significantly more effective than surgical management, leading to higher rates of clinical resolution (see Question 30).
  • In patients with a suspected scaphoid fracture but negative radiograph, immediate MRI or CT is more cost-effective than splinting and repeat radiography when follow-up care, missed fracture, and lost productivity are taken into account (see Question 19).
  • Most medial collateral ligament and posterior cruciate ligament tears do not require surgery and can be managed conservatively.
  • Patellofemoral pain syndrome is characterized by pain in the knee that may be localized to the patella or behind the patella and classically occurs with activities that involve knee flexion; imaging is not necessary to establish the diagnosis (see Question 50).
  • The diagnosis of iliotibial band syndrome can be made when repeated flexion and extension of the supine patient’s knee with the thumb over the lateral femoral condyle reproduces the patient’s pain; imaging is not necessary (see Question 28).
  • In patients treated with statin therapy, liver chemistry tests and muscle enzyme studies should not be routinely obtained in the absence of symptoms of liver dysfunction or myopathy.
  • In the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia, evidence of a beneficial effect for omega-3 fatty acid supplements other than icosapent ethyl is lacking (see Question 60).
  • For initial acute treatment of major depressive disorder, options include cognitive behavioral therapy or second-generation antidepressants after consideration and discussion of side effects, cost, accessibility, and patient preferences; combination therapy is a reasonable option, especially in moderate to severe disease.
  • Nonpharmacologic therapy, including lifestyle modification and behavioral therapy, is the preferred treatment for all types of urinary incontinence.
  • Alternating air mattresses for pressure injury prevention are not recommended, based on cost considerations and no evidence of clear advantage (see Question 98).
  • Evidence is insufficient to assess the safety and efficacy of hyperbaric oxygen therapy for pressure injuries (see Question 51).
  • Actinic purpura is the result of blood vessel fragility and dermal atrophy from aging; no additional testing needs to be done, and no treatment is required.
  • Results on direct-to-consumer genomic testing should be confirmed with a clinical test before being used for medical decision making (see Question 73).
bookHvc.cv:
• Cardiac stress testing is not routinely recommended in asymptomatic patients with diabetes mellitus to detect subclinical coronary artery disease.
  • With few exceptions, fasting and nonfasting total cholesterol and HDL cholesterol levels have fairly similar prognostic value and association with cardiovascular outcomes (see Question 19).
  • No study has demonstrated the benefit of intensifying lipid management, such as with the initiation of ezetimibe, when LDL cholesterol level is lower than 70 mg/dL (1.81 mmol/L) (see Question 21).
  • There is no role for dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel in patients with chronic stable angina in the absence of revascularization (see Question 41).
  • Current guidelines recommend against routine surveillance echocardiography in patients with chronic heart failure in the absence of a change in clinical status or planned intervention.
  • For patients with new-onset heart failure, directly initiating valsartan-sacubitril rather than a pretreatment period with an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker, is a safe and effective strategy in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (see Question 1).
  • Serial B-type natriuretic peptide measurements should not be used to guide care of patients with chronic heart failure.
  • Routine invasive pulmonary artery catheterization for hemodynamic monitoring is not recommended in patients with decompensated heart failure.
  • Two key elements are associated with a successful transition to home following hospitalization for heart failure: a follow-up phone call within 2 to 3 days of discharge and an office visit within 7 to 14 days of hospital discharge (see Question 52).
  • In patients with atrial fibrillation, rivaroxaban is noninferior to warfarin in the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism and is associated with less intracranial and fatal bleeding (see Question 11).
  • Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) without high-risk features (syncope, family history of premature sudden cardiac death, structural heart disease) are managed with reassurance; treatment is reserved for bothersome symptoms or frequent PVCs.
  • Device pocket infection is a clinical diagnosis; aspiration of a cardiac implantable device pocket should never be performed for diagnostic purposes (see Question 64).
  • In patients with valvular heart disease who are at high risk for infective endocarditis, antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography, esophagogastroduodenoscopy, colonoscopy, or cystoscopy, in the absence of active infection (see Question 108).
  • In patients with suspected infective endocarditis (IE), transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is recommended as the initial imaging study in most clinical situations; in all patients with known or suspected IE and nondiagnostic TTE results, or if complications have developed or are clinically suspected or if intracardiac device leads are present, transesophageal echocardiography is recommended (see Question 18).
  • Genetic testing is not indicated in first-degree relatives of patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy unless a pathogenic genetic variant is identified in the index patient.
  • No treatment or follow-up is needed in asymptomatic patients with a patent foramen ovale.
  • In patients with peripheral artery disease and intermittent claudication, supervised exercise training is the most effective treatment for improving maximal walking distance and pain-free walking distance (see Question 86).
  • There is no evidence to support the use of dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel over antiplatelet monotherapy in patients with peripheral artery disease (see Question 3).
  • Neither pentoxifylline nor chelation therapy with ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has any benefit for the treatment of symptomatic peripheral artery disease (see Question 86).
